sections.title:
Limitwise monotonic functions relative to the Kleene's Ordinal
Notation System
sections.abstract:
In this paper we generalize the theorem that previously
obtained by the authors for a wider class of linear orders using
$X$-limitwise monotonic functions relative to the Kleene's Ordinal
Notation System.
sections.author: Frolov A.\,N., Zubkov M.\,V.
sections.shorttit:
LMF relative to the Kleene's Notation
System
sections.keywords: Computable linear orders, limitwise monotonic functions, Ordinal Notations System
sections.introduction:
All definitions of Computability Theory can be found in
\cite{Soare}, all definitions of Computable Linear Order Theory can
be found in \cite{Rosenstein}.

We recall only necessary definitions from Computable Linear Order
Theory. A countable linear ordering is called {\it computable}($X$-computable), if its universe and its order relation are both
computable ($X$-computable, resp.). The {\it successor relation} of
a linear order $\mathcal{L}$ is $S_\mathcal{L}(x,y)
\leftrightharpoons (x <_\mathcal{L} y) \,\&\, \lnot (\exists z) (x
<_\mathcal{L} z <_\mathcal{L} y)$. The {\it block relation} of
$\mathcal{L}$ is $F_\mathcal{L}(x,y) \leftrightharpoons (x
\le_\mathcal{L} y) \,\&\, |[x,y]_\mathcal{L}| < +\infty$, where
$|[x,y]|_\mathcal{L} = \{z \mid x \le_\mathcal{L} z \le_\mathcal{L}
y\}$.

A {\it factor order}$\mathcal{L}/F_\mathcal{L}$ of $\mathcal{L}$ is
defined by $[x]_\mathcal{L}<_{\mathcal{L}/F_\mathcal{L}}
[y]_\mathcal{L}\Leftrightarrow x<_\mathcal{L}y$. We define the
relations $F^\alpha_{\mathcal{L}}$ for any ordinal $\alpha$ as
follows:

$F^0_{\mathcal{L}}(x,\,y)\Leftrightarrow x=y$,
$[x]^0_{\mathcal{L}}\rightleftharpoons\{y\in L\mid
F^0_{\mathcal{L}}(x,\,y) \}$;

if $\alpha=\beta+1$ then
$F^{\beta+1}_{\mathcal{L}}(x,\,y)\Leftrightarrow
F_{{\mathcal{L}}/F^\beta_{\mathcal{L}}}([x]^\beta_{\mathcal{L}},\,
[y]^\beta_{\mathcal{L}})$,
$[x]^\beta_{\mathcal{L}}\rightleftharpoons\{y\in L\mid
F^\beta_{\mathcal{L}}(x,\,y) \}$;

if $\alpha$ is a limit ordinal then
$F^{\alpha}_{\mathcal{L}}(x,\,y)\Leftrightarrow (\exists
\beta<\alpha)[
F_{{\mathcal{L}}/F^\beta_{\mathcal{L}}}([x]^\beta_{\mathcal{L}},\,
[y]^\beta_{\mathcal{L}})]$,
$[x]^\alpha_{\mathcal{L}}\rightleftharpoons\{y\in L\mid (\exists
\beta<\alpha)[F^\beta_{\mathcal{L}}(x,\,y)]\}$.

We note that $F^1_{\mathcal{L}}(x,\,y)\Leftrightarrow
F_{\mathcal{L}}(x,\,y)$. We denote $\mathcal{L}^{(0)}_F=\mathcal{L}$
and $\mathcal{L}^{(\alpha)}_F=\mathcal{L}/F^\alpha_\mathcal{L}$, for
all ordinal $\alpha$.

Earlier, the authors \cite{Frolov-Zubkov} have proved the following


\begin{theorem}
Let $\mathcal{L}$ be a countable linear order $\mathcal{L}$ without
the least and the great elements. Suppose that the block relation of
$\mathcal{L}$ is finite. The following conditions are equivalent:

1) $\mathcal{L}$ has a $\Delta_2^0$-computable copy with
$\Delta_2^0$-computable the successor and the block relations;

2) $\mathcal{L}$ has a $\Delta_2^0$-computable copy with
$\Delta_2^0$-computable the block relation;

3) $\mathcal{L}\cong\sum\limits_{q\in\mathds{Q}}G(q)$, where $G :
\mathds{Q} \longrightarrow \mathds{N}$ and $epigr(G)\in\Pi_2^0$,

4) $\mathcal{L}\cong\sum\limits_{q\in\mathds{Q}}G(q)$, where $G :
\mathds{Q} \longrightarrow \mathds{N}$ and $G(q) =
\liminf\limits_{s\to\infty} g(q,s)$ for any $q\in\mathds{Q}$ and
some computable function $g$,

5) $\mathcal{\mathcal{L}}$ has a computable copy with
$\Pi_1^0$-computable the block relation.
\end{theorem}
It is easy to see that Condition 4 of the theorem is equivalent to
the condition that the function $G$ is limitwise monotonic function
(see \cite{Downey-Turetsky}). We recall the definition of limitwise
monotonic functions.

\begin{definition}\label{lmf-def}
A function $F$ is called \textit{$X$-limitwise monotonic}, if there
is an  $X$-computable  function $f(x,\,s)$ such that $(\forall
x)(\forall s) [f(x,\,s)\leq f(x,\,s+1)]$;\quad  $(\forall x) [
F(x)=\lim\limits_{s\rightarrow\infty} f(x,\,s)]$.
\end{definition}
In this paper we generalize this definition taking functions with
constructive ordinals values.

\begin{definition}\label{new-lmf}
A function $F:\omega\longrightarrow{\omega^{CK}_1}$ is called
$X$-limitwise monotonic relative to the Kleene's Ordinal Notation
System $\textit{O}$, if there is an $X$-computab\-le function
$f:\omega\times\omega\longrightarrow\omega$ such that (1)
{$\lim\limits_{s\to\infty}|f(x,\,s)|_{\mathcal{O}}=F(x)$;} \quad (2)
{$(\forall s\in\omega)[f(x,\,s)\leq_\textit{O} f(x,\,s+1)]$.}
\end{definition}
We remark that if functions $F, G:\omega\longrightarrow{\omega^{CK}_1}$ is $X$-limitwise monotonic relative to the Kleene's
Ordinal Notation System, then the functions $F+G$, $F\cdot G$,
$\max\{F,\,G\}$,  $\min\{F,\,G\}$ are also $X$-limitwise monotonic
relative to the Kleene's Ordinal Notation System.

In this paper we generalize the Theorem \ref{lmf-def} for a wider
class of linear orders using $X$-limitwise monotonic functions
relative to the Kleene's Ordinal Notation System.

The Kleene's Ordinal Notation System was introduced and investigated
by A. Curch's and S. Kleene's \cite{Church Kleene} -- %\cite{Church},\cite{Kleene}. More details you can find in \cite{Rogers} and
\cite{Arslanov}.

\begin{definition}
A notation system $S$ is a mapping $\nu_S$ from a subset $D_S$ of
natural numbers to an initial segment of ordinal numbers such that

\begin{enumerate}
\item{there is a partial computable function $k_S$ such that\\
if $\nu_S(x)=0$, then $k_S(x)=0$;\\
if $\nu_S(x)$ is a successor, then $k_S(x)=1$;\\
if $\nu_S(x)$ is a limit ordinal, then $k_S(x)=2$;}

\item{there is a partial computable function $p_S$ such that
if $\nu_S(x)$ is a successor, then $p_S(x)\downarrow$ and
$\nu_S(x)=\nu_S(p_S(x))+1$;}

\item{there is a partial computable function $q_S$ such that
if $\nu_S(x)$ is a limit ordinal, then $q_S(x)\downarrow$, the
function $\Phi_{q_S(x)}$ is total, and
 a consequence $\{\nu_S(\Phi_{q_S(x)}(n))\}_{n\in\omega}$
is the increasing and it convergence to $\nu_S(x)$.}
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}
Suppose $S$ is a notation system. Elements of $D_S$ is called
notations of $S$. There are partial computable functions $\lambda_S$
and $\phi_S$ such that $\nu_S(x)=\lambda_S(x)+\phi_S(x)$,
$\lambda_S(x)$ is a limit ordinal, and $\phi_S(x)$ is a finite
ordinal.

An ordinal $\alpha$ is called {\it constructive}, if there is a
notation system which contains a notation for $\alpha$. It is well
know that every ordinal is constructive if an only if it is
computable.

\begin{definition}[The Kleene's Ordinal Notation System $\textit{O}$]
We define map $|\cdot|_\mathcal{O}$ from a subset $D_{\mathcal{O}}$
of natural numbers to ordinals as follows
\begin{enumerate}
\item{$|1|_\mathcal{O}=0$;}

\item{$|2^n|_\mathcal{O}=\beta+1$, if $|n|_\mathcal{O}$ is defined and
$|n|_\mathcal{O}=\beta$;}

\item{$|3\cdot5^e|_\mathcal{O}=\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}|\Phi_e(n)|_\mathcal{O}$,
if, for all $n$, $\Phi_e(n)\downarrow$,
$|\Phi_e(n)|_\mathcal{O}\downarrow$, and
$|\Phi_e(n)|_\mathcal{O}<|\Phi_e(n+1)|_\mathcal{O}$.}
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}
A domain of $|\cdot|_\mathcal{O}$ we denote by $\textit{O}$. Below
we give the definition of partial order $<_\textit{O}$ on
$\textit{O}$.

\begin{definition}
For all $x\in\textit{O}$, we put $2<_\textit{O}2^x$. If
$z\in\textit{O}$ and $z<_\textit{O}x$ then we put
$z<_\textit{O}2^x$. And we define $z<_\textit{O}3\cdot 5^e$ for all
$e\in\omega$, $z\in\textit{O}$ such that $z<_\textit{O}\Phi_e(n)$
for some $n$.
\end{definition}
By the definition, if $x<_\textit{O}y$, then
$|x|_\mathcal{O}<|y|_\mathcal{O}$. The converse is not true.

Additionally, there is a function $+_\textit{O}$ which is called the
Kleene's sum such that
\begin{enumerate}
\item{$(\forall x,\,y\in\textit{O})[x+_\textit{O}y\in\textit{O}]$;}
\item{$(\forall x,\,y\in\textit{O})[y\neq 1\rightarrow x<_\textit{O}x+_\textit{O}y]$;}
\item{$(\forall
x,\,y\in\textit{O})[|x+_\textit{O}y|_\mathcal{O}=|x|_\mathcal{O}+|y|_\mathcal{O}]$.}
\end{enumerate}
main_part:
\begin{proposition}\label{lmf-equivalence}
Let $F:\omega\longrightarrow{\omega^{CK}_1}$. The following are
equivalent:

(1) {$F$ is $X'$-limitwise monotonic relative to the Kleene's
Ordinal Notation System;}

(2) there is an $X$-computable function
$f:\omega\times\omega\longrightarrow\omega$ such that a)
$\liminf\limits_{s\to\infty}|f(x,\,s)|_{\mathcal{O}}=F(x)$; b)
$f(x,\,s)$ and $f(x,\,s+1)$ are comparable with respect to the order
$<_\textit{O}$ for all $s\in\omega$.
\end{proposition}\begin{proof}
$(1) \Rightarrow (2).$ Since the function  $F$ is $X'$-limitwise
monotonic relative to the Kleene's Ordinal Notation System, there is
an $X'$-computable function $g$ satisfying properties 1--2 of
Definition \ref{new-lmf}. Clearly, there is an $X$-computable
relation $R$ such that, for any $x$ and $y$,
$$(\forall s)[\neg(y<_O g(x,\,s))] \Leftrightarrow (\forall
u)(\exists v)[R(x,y,u,v)].$$

Let $ln_R(x,y,s)=\max\{k\leq s \mid (\forall u\leq k) (\exists v\leq
s) [R(x,y,u,v)]\}$. We have $(\forall u)(\exists v)[R(x,y,u,v)]$ if
and only if $(\exists^{\infty} s)[(ln_R(x,y,s+1)>ln_R(x,y,s))]$. We
define an $X$-computable function $f$ as follows: $f(x, 0)=0$; if
there is $y\leq s$ such that $ln_R(x,y,s+1)
> ln_R(x,y,s)$, then we define $f(x,s+1) =
\min_\textit{O}\{y\leq s \mid ln_R(x,y,s+1) >_O
ln_R(x,y,s)\}$. Otherwise, we define $f(x,s+1) = g(x,s)$.

We have $F(x)=\alpha$ if and only if $\alpha = \min
\{|y'|_\mathcal{O} \mid (\forall u) (\exists v) [R(x,y',u,v)]\}$. It
is equal to $y = \min\{|y'|_\mathcal{O} \mid (\exists^{\infty} s)
[ln_R(x,y',s+1) > ln_R(x,y',s)]\}$. So, $F(x)=\alpha$ if and only if
$\liminf\limits_{s\to\infty} |g(x,s)|_\mathcal{O} = \alpha$.



$(2) \Rightarrow (1).$ Suppose a function
$f:\omega\times\omega\longrightarrow\omega$ satisfies  a) and b) of
the proposition. We define a function
$\tilde{f}:\omega\times\omega\longrightarrow\omega$ using the oracle
$X'$. For all $x\in\omega$, we put $\tilde{f}(x,\,0)=0$. If
$(\exists u>s+1)[ f(x,\,u)<_\textit{O} f(x,\,s+1)]$, then we put
$\tilde{f}(x,\,s+1)=\tilde{f}(x,\,s)$. Otherwise, we put
$\tilde{f}(x,\,s+1)=f(x,\,s+1)$. It easy to check that
$\lim\limits_{s\to\infty}|\tilde{f}(x,\,s)|_{\mathcal{O}}
=\liminf\limits_{s\to\infty}|f(x,\,s)|_\mathcal{O} = F(x)$ for all
$x\in\omega$, and $(\forall s\in\omega) [\tilde{f}(x,\,s)
\leq_\textit{O} \tilde{f}(x,\,s+1)]$. So, $F$ is $X'$-limitwise
monotonic relative to the Kleene's Ordinal Notation System.
\end{proof}\begin{proposition}\label{nonlimit}
Suppose $f(x,\,y):\omega\times \omega\longrightarrow\textit{O}$ is a
computable function. Then there is a computable function
$g(x,\,y):\omega\times \omega\longrightarrow\textit{O}$ such that
$\liminf\limits_{s\to\infty}
|f(x,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}=\liminf\limits_{s\to\infty}
|g(x,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}$ and $(\forall x)(\forall
s)[|g(x,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}>0\rightarrow (\exists
\beta\in{\omega^{CK}_1})[\beta+1=|g(x,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}]]$.
\end{proposition}\begin{proof}
If $|f(x,s+1)|_\mathcal{O}$ is equal to null or it is not a limit
ordinal (i.e. $f(x, s+1)\neq 3\cdot5^e$), then we define
$g(x,s+1)=f(x,s+1)$. Let $|f(x, s+1)|_\mathcal{O}$ be a limit
ordinal. We have $f(x, s+1)= 3\cdot5^e$ for some $e$ and hence
$|f(x,s+1)|_\mathcal{O}=\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}|\Phi_e(n)|_\mathcal{O}$.
There are two possibilities. If $f(x, s+1)\leq_\mathcal{O} f(x, s)$,
then we find the least $n$ such that
$\Phi_e(n)>_O\max_\mathcal{O}\{g(x,u)\mid u\leq s,
g(x,\,u)<_Of(x,\,s+1)\}$. If $f(x, s+1)>_O f(x, s)$, we find the
least $n$ such that $\Phi_e(n)>_O f(x,s)$. In both cases we define
$g(x,s+1)=\Phi_e(n)$. It easy to check that
$\liminf\limits_{s\to\infty}
|f(x,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}=\liminf\limits_{s\to\infty}
|g(x,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}$.
\end{proof}\begin{proposition}\label{ltc}
Suppose
$\mathcal{L}\cong\sum\limits_{q\in\mathds{Q}}(H(q)^*+1+K(q))$, where
$H$ and $K$ are $\emptyset'$-limitwise monotonic functions relative
to the Kleene's Ordinal Notation System $\textit{O}$.

Then $\mathcal{L}$ has a computable copy with $\Sigma^0_1$ unary
predicate $U(x)$ which marked elements corresponding by 1 from
sentence $\sum\limits_{q\in\mathds{Q}}(H(q)^*+1+K(q))$. Moreover, if
functions $H$ and $K$ bounded by constructive ordinal $\alpha$, then
the computable copy of $\mathcal{\mathcal{L}}$ has
$\Pi_1^0$-com\-pu\-tab\-le relations $F^\beta_\mathcal{L}$
($1\leq\beta\leq\alpha$).
\end{proposition}\begin{proof}
We construct an uniformly computable sequence
$\{I_s(q)\}_{s\in\mathds{N},\,q\in\mathds{Q}}$ of linear orders such
that $I(q) = \lim\limits_{s\to\infty}I_s(q)$ is a computable linear
order of a type $\gamma^*+1+\delta$ (where
$\gamma,\,\delta\leq\omega_1^{CK}$), and $\mathcal{T} =
\sum\limits_{q\in\mathds{Q}}I(q)$ is a computable linear order which
is isomorphic to $\mathcal{L}$. The linear order $I_s(q)$ has 3
parts (perhaps empty), i.~e., $I_q(s)=L_q(s)+\{c_q\}+R_q(s)$. The
construction of $L_q(s)$ is symmetric to the construction of
$R_q(s)$. So, without loss of generality we consider only the
construction of $R_q(s)$.

We use ordinals notations from suitable branches of the Kleene's
Ordinal Notation System as indexes. By misuse of language, we write
ordinal instead of its notations. It will not cause
misunderstanding. Also when in the construction we put a new element
to $T$, we find the least number $t\notin T$ in the standard order
of natural numbers. If we put an infinite set of elements, then we
find an infinite computable set such that it contains the least
element which is not in $T$, and the set and its complement contain
infinitely many elements which are not used in the construction. In
other words, the universe of $\mathcal{\mathcal{T}}$ will be the set
of natural numbers $\mathds{N}$.

Suppose $N_{\mathds{Q}} : \mathds{Q} \longrightarrow \mathds{N}$ is
a computable bijection. By Proposition \ref{nonlimit}, there is a
computable function $k(x,\,s)$ such that $K(q) =
\liminf\limits_{s\to\infty}|k(q,s)|_\mathcal{O} = \alpha$ for all
$q$ (such function exists). We remark that $|k(x,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}$
are successor or $0$ for all $x, s$.

\textit{The conctruction.}

\textit{Stage $s=0$.} $I_0(q)$ is undefined for all $q\in\mathds{Q}$.

\textit{Stage $s+1$.} For all $q\in\mathds{Q}$ we define
$I_{s+1}(q)$ such that $N_{\mathds{Q}}(q)\le s$. We consider two
cases.

\textit{ Case 1.} Suppose $I_s(q)$ is defined and $I_s(q)
=L_s(q)+\{c_q\}+R_s(q)$, where $R_s(q)=\{r_1 <_\mathcal{T} r_2
<_\mathcal{T} \ldots <_\mathcal{T} r_{|k(q,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}}\}$. If
$k(q,\,s+1) = k(q,\,s)$, then we do nothing. If $k(q,\,s+1)>_O
k(q,s)$, we add a new (perhaps infinite) interval
$r_{|k(q,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}+1}<_\mathcal{T} \ldots <_\mathcal{T}
r_{|k(q,\,s+1)|_\mathcal{O}}$ to $R_s(q)$ and we defined $R_{s+1}(q)
= \{r_1<_\mathcal{T} \ldots <_\mathcal{T} r_{|k(x,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}}
<_\mathcal{T} r_{|k(x,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}+1} <_\mathcal{T} \ldots
<_\mathcal{T} r_{|k(q,\,s+1)|_\mathcal{O}}\}$. If $k(q,\,s+1) <_O
k(q,\,s)$ then we defined $R_{s+1}(q) = \{r_1 <_\mathcal{T} \ldots
<_\mathcal{T} r_{|k(q,\,s+1)|_\mathcal{O}}\}$ and call all
$r_{{|k(q,\,s+1)|_\mathcal{O}}+1} <_\mathcal{T} \ldots
<_\mathcal{T}r_{|k(q,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}}$ as {\it free} (i.e. thus
elements do not connect with $I_{s+1}(u)$ for all $u\in\mathds{Q}$).

\textit{ Case 2.} Suppose $I_s(q)$ is not defined. Also, suppose that $-\infty <_{\mathds{Q}} u <_{\mathds{Q}}
+\infty$ for all $u\in\mathds{Q}$, and $I_t(-\infty)=\{-\infty\}$, $I_t(+\infty)=\{+\infty\}$ are defined
for all $t\in\mathds{N}$. Moreover, $-\infty <_\mathcal{T} z
<_\mathcal{T} +\infty$ for all $z\in \mathcal{T}$. We find $q_1,
q_2 \in \mathds{Q}\bigcup\{-\infty, +\infty\}$ such that $q_1
<_{\mathds{Q}} q <_{\mathds{Q}} q_2$, $I_s(q_1)$ and $I_s(q_2)$ are defined and there is no $q_3$ such that $q_1 <_{\mathds{Q}}
q_3 <_{\mathds{Q}} q_2$ and $I_s(q_3)$ is defined.

We find the least $x_0$ (in the standard order on $\mathds{N}$) such
that $x_0$ \textit{is free} and lies between $I_s(q_1)$ and
$I_s(q_2)$. If there is no such $x_0$ then we add a new
\textit{free} element $x_0$ to $\mathcal{T}$ between $I_s(q_1)$ and
$I_s(q_2)$. Thus, we define $c_q=x_0$ and $R_{s+1}(q)=\{x_1
<_\mathcal{T }x_2 <_\mathcal{T} \ldots <_\mathcal{T}
x_{|k(q,\,s+1)|_\mathcal{O}}\}$, where $x_1,\dots,
x_{|k(q,\,s+1)|_\mathcal{O}}$ are new elements. Note that
$R_{s+1}(q)$ is empty, if $|k(q,\,s+1)|_\mathcal{O}=0$.

\textit{End of the construction.}

Suppose $K(q)=\alpha$ then
$\liminf\limits_{s\to\infty}|k(q,s)|_\mathcal{O} = \alpha$. It easy
to check that there are elements $x_1, \dots, x_\alpha$ and stage
$s_0$ such that $(\forall s\ge s_0)[x_1, \dots, x_\alpha \in
R_{s}(q)]$ and $(\forall x\not\in \{x_i \mid 1\le i\le n\})(\exists
s')(\forall s\ge s')[x\notin I_{s}(q)]$. Hence
$R(q)=\lim\limits_{s\to\infty}R_s(q)$ is well defined and
$R(q)\cong\alpha$. Thus,
$\sum\limits_{q\in\mathds{Q}}(H(q)^*+1+K(q)) \cong
\sum\limits_{q\in\mathds{Q}}I(q)$.

Suppose that $y\in I(q_y)$ for all $y < x$ and $x$ is a
\textit{free} element on some stage $s_1$. There are rational
numbers $q_1$, $q_2$ such that $N_{\mathds{Q}}(q_1),
N_{\mathds{Q}}(q_2) \le s_1$, $I_{s_1}(q_1)$ and $I_{s_1}(q_2)$ are
successor intervals, and $x$ lies between $I_{s_1}(q_1)$ and
$I_{s_1}(q_2)$.

Then there is a stage $s_2 \ge s_1$ such that $I_{s}(q_1)$ and
$I_{s}(q_2)$ are successor intervals on the stage $s_2$, $q_1
<_{\mathds{Q}} q_3 <_{\mathds{Q}} q_2$ for some $q_3$ with
$N_{\mathds{Q}}(q_3) = s_2+1$. By the construction, $x$ is $c_{q_3}$
from $I_{s_2+1}(q_3)$. Hence, $x\in I_{s}(q_3)$ for all $s\ge
s_2+1$. Thus, the linear order
$\mathcal{T}=\sum\limits_{q\in\mathds{Q}}I(q)$ is computable.

Obviously, that $U(x)$ if and only if  $x=c_q$ for some $q$ and
hence $U\in\Sigma^0_1$. By the construction, if $x\in I_s(q_1)$,
$y\in I_s(q_2)$ and $q_1 \not= q_2$ for some stage $s$, then $\lnot
F_\mathcal{T}(x,y)$. Therefore, $F_\mathcal{T}\in\Pi_1^0$.
\end{proof}\begin{theorem}\label{order-equivalence}
Suppose $\mathcal{L}$ is a linear order such that
$\mathcal{L}\cong\sum\limits_{q\in\mathds{Q}}(E(q)^*+1+G(q))$, where
$E,\,G:\mathds{Q}\longrightarrow\omega_1^{CK}$. Let $U$ be an unary
predicate which marked elements corresponding 1 from sentence
$\sum\limits_{q\in\mathds{Q}}(E(q)^*+1+G(q))$. If $E$ and $G$ are
bounded by a constructive ordinal $\alpha$, then the following
conditions are equivalent:

1. $\mathcal{L}$ has a $\Delta_2^0$-computable copy with
$\Delta_2^0$-computable relations $S_\mathcal{L}$,
$F^\beta_\mathcal{L}$ (uniformly by $\beta$,
$1\leq\beta\leq\alpha$), and a $\Delta_2^0$-computable predicate
$U$;

2. $\mathcal{L}$ has a $\Delta_2^0$-computable copy with
$\Delta_2^0$-computable relations $F^\beta_\mathcal{L}$ (uniformly
by $\beta$, $1\leq\beta\leq\alpha$), and a $\Delta_2^0$-computable
predicate $U$;

3. $E$ and $G$ are $\emptyset'$-limiwise monotonic relative to the
Kleene's Ordinal Notation System;

4. $E(q) = \liminf\limits_{s\to\infty} |e(q,s)|_\mathcal{O}$,
$G(q) = \liminf\limits_{s\to\infty} |g(q,s)|_\mathcal{O}$ for all $q\in\mathds{Q}$ and some computable functions
$e,\,g:\omega\times\omega\longrightarrow\omega$.

5. $\mathcal{\mathcal{L}}$ has a computable copy with
$\Pi_1^0$-computable relations $F^\beta_\mathcal{L}$
($\beta\leq\alpha$) and with a $\Sigma^0_1$-computable predicate
$U$.
\end{theorem}
Before to proved the theorem we demonstrate our ideas for a case
$\alpha< \omega^\omega$.

\begin{lemma}\label{tech-lem}
Suppose $\mathcal{L}$ is from Theorem \ref{order-equivalence} such
that the functions $E$ and $G$ are bounded by an ordinal
$\alpha<\omega^\omega$. The following conditions are equivalent:

 $\mathcal{L}$ has a $\Delta_2^0$-computable copy with
$\Delta_2^0$-computable relations $F^\beta_\mathcal{L}$ (uniformly
by $\beta$, where $\beta\leq n$ and $n=\min\{\gamma\mid \alpha\leq
\omega^\gamma\}$), and a $\Delta_2^0$-computable predicate $U$;

 $E$ and $G$ are $\emptyset'$-limitwise monotonic relative to the
Kleene's Ordinal Notation System.
\end{lemma}\begin{proof}
Suppose $\tilde{\mathcal{L}}$ is a suborder of $\mathcal{L}$ such
that $\tilde{L}=\{x\in L\mid U(x)\}$. Hence, $\tilde{\mathcal{L}}$
is a $\Delta_2^0$-computable linear order and $\tilde{\mathcal{L}}
\cong \mathds{Q}$. Then there is a $\Delta_2^0$-computable
isomorphism $\varphi$ from $\tilde{\mathcal{L}}$ to $\mathds{Q}$.

Suppose the Cantor normal form for $G(q)$ is
$\omega^{n_1(q)}+\omega^{n_2(q)}+\cdots+\omega^{n_m(q)}+k(q)$, where
$n_1(q)\geq n_2(q)\geq \cdots \geq n_m(q)$ and $k(q)>0$. It is easy to check that $n_1(q)$ is the least number such that
$$|\{t>_\mathcal{L}\varphi^{-1}(q)\mid F^{n_1+2}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,t)\,\&\,
\neg F^{n_1+1}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,t) \}|=0.$$

Suppose $u_1(q)=\min_\mathcal{L}\{u\mid
F^{n_1+1}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,u)\,\&\, \neg
F^{n_1}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,u) \}$. We can effectively find elements $n_i(q)$ and $u_i(q)$ for $1\leq
i<n_m(q)$ by induction. $$n_{i+1}(q)=\min\{n\in\omega\mid
|\{t\geq_\mathcal{L}u_i(q)\mid F^{n+2}_\mathcal{L}(u_i(q),\,t)\,\&\,\neg F^{n+1}_\mathcal{L}(u_i,\,t)\}|=0\}\ ,$$
$$u_{i+1}(q)=\min\nolimits_\mathcal{L}\{u\mid
F^{n_{i+1}(q)+1}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,u)\,\&\, \neg
F^{n_{i+1}(q)}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,u) \}\ .$$ and
$k(q)=|\{t\geq_\mathcal{L}u_m(q)\mid F^1_\mathcal{L}(u_m(q),\,t)\}|$.

Suppose that the Cantor normal form of $G(q)$ is
$\omega^{n_1(q)}+\cdots+\omega^{n_m(q)+1}$ then
$G(q)=\omega^{n_1(q)}+\cdots+\omega^{n_m(q)}+\omega^{n_m(q)}+\omega^{n_m(q)}+\cdots$.
We can effectively find elements $n_i(q)$ and $u_i(q)$ in the same
way but for all $i\in\omega$. In this case we have infinity
sequences $u_i(q) (i\in\omega)$ and
$n_1(q)\geq\,n_2(q)\geq\cdots\geq
n_m(q)=n_{m+1}(q)=n_{m+2}(q)=\cdots$.

Now we show that function $G$ is limitwise monotonic. We build
approximation using elements $t$ not greater then $s$. Then we have
uniformly $\emptyset'$-computable functions $n_j(q,\,s)$ ($j\geq 1$)
and $k(q,\,s)$. We add formally new element $u_\infty$ to $\mathcal{L}$ (suppose $u_\infty>_{\mathcal{L}}u$ for all $u\in L$). We
define
$$n_1(q,\,s)=\min(\{0\}\cup\{n\in\omega\mid |\{t\in L\mid
t>_\mathcal{L}\varphi^{-1}(q)\,\&\,t<s\,\&$$
$$\,F^{n+2}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,t)\,\&\, \neg F^{n+1}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,t) \}|=0\}),$$
$$u_1(q,\,s)=\min\nolimits_\mathcal{L}(\{u_\infty\}\cup\{u\in L\mid
F^{n_1(q,\,s)+1}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,u)\,\&\, \neg
F^{n_1(q,\,s)}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,u) \}),$$
$$n_{i+1}(q,\,s)=\min(\{0\}\cup\{n\in\omega\mid |\{t\in L\mid t\geq_\mathcal{L}u_i(q,\,s)\& $$
$$t<s \,\&\, F^{n+2}_\mathcal{L}(u_i(q,\,s),\,t)\,\&\,\neg
F^{n+1}_\mathcal{L}(u_i(q,\,s),\,t)\}|=0\}),$$
$$u_{i+1}(q,\,s)=\min\nolimits_\mathcal{L}(\{u_\infty\}\cup\{u\in L\mid
F^{n_{i+1}(q,\,s)+1}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,u)\,\&\, \neg
F^{n_{i+1}(q,\,s)}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,u) \}).$$

Suppose $u_f(q,\,s)=\max_\mathcal{L}(\{\varphi^{-1}(q)\}\cup\{u\in
L\mid \exists i<s\,[u=u_i(q,\,s)\,\&\, n_i(q,\,s)=0]\})$. We define
$k(q,\,s)=|\{t\in L\mid F^1_\mathcal{L}(u_f(q,\,s),\,t)\}|$.

Let $\hat{g}(q,\,s)=\sum\limits_{i=1}^s
sg(n_i(q,\,s))\cdot\omega^{n_i(q,\,s)}+k(q,\,s)$, where $sg(x)=1$ if
$x>0$ and $sg(x)=0$ if $x=0$. We have
$\hat{g}(q,\,s)\leq\hat{g}(q,\,s+1)$ and $\lim\limits_{s\to\infty}
\hat{g}(q,\,s)=G(q).$ There are two cases.

Case 1. $G(q)=\omega^{n_1(q)}+ \omega^{n_2(q)}+\cdots+
\omega^{n_m(q)+1}$, i.e., the last summand is the power of $\omega$ (and since the power is a finite ordinal hence it is a successor).

Case 2. $G(q)=\omega^{n_1(q)}+\omega^{n_2(q)}+\cdots+
\omega^{n_m(q)}+k(q)$, i.e., the last summand is a
finite ordinal.

By the definition of $n_i(q)$ and $n_i(q,\,s)$, in both cases we
have $\lim\limits_{s\to\infty} n_j(q,\,s)=n_j(q)$ for any $j<m$. In
fact, $(\exists s_0)(\forall s>s_0)[n_j(q,\,s)=n_j(q)]$. In the
first case, we have $\lim\limits_{s\to
\infty}n_j(q,\,s)=n_m(q)$ for any $j\geq m$. Hence,
$\lim\limits_{s\to \infty}(\sum\limits_{t=m}^{s}sg(n_t(q,\,s))
\cdot\omega^{n_t(q,\,s)}+k(q,\,s))= \omega^{n_m(q)+1}$. In the
second case, we have  $\lim\limits_{s\to
\infty}n_t(q,\,s)=n_m(q)$, $\lim\limits_{s\to
\infty}k(q,\,s)=k(q)$, and $\lim\limits_{s\to \infty}n_j(q,\,s)=0$
for any $j> m$. Therefore,
$\lim\limits_{s\to\infty}(\sum\limits_{i=1}^s
sg(n_i(q,\,s))\cdot\omega^{n_i(q,\,s)}+k(q,\,s))=G(q)$.


If $n_i(q,\,s)>n_i(q,\,s+1)$ then there is $j<i$ such that
$n_j(q,\,s)<n_j(q,\,s+1)$. Hence, there is an index $l$ such that
$n_l(q,\,s)<n_l(q,\,s+1)$ and $n_r(q,\,s)=n_r(q,\,s+1)$ for any
$r<l$. Then
$\hat{g}(q,\,s)=\sum\limits_{i=1}^s\omega^{n_i(q,\,s)}+k(q,\,s)
<\sum\limits_{i=1}^l\omega^{n_i(q,\,s+1)}\leq
\sum\limits_{i=1}^s\omega^{n_i(q,\,s+1)}+k(q,\,s+1)=\hat{g}(q,\,s+1)$.
Similarly, if $k(q,\,s)>k(q,\,s+1)$, then there is $j\leq s+1$ such
that $n_j(q,\,s)<n_j(q,\,s+1)$.

It easy to build a computable function $g(q,\,s)$ such that
$|g(q,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}=\hat{g}(q,\,s)$, and Condition 2 from the
definition of limitwise monotonic functions relative to the Kleene's
Ordinal Notation System holds. Hence,
$G(q)=\lim\limits_{s\to\infty}|g(q,\,s)|_\mathcal{O}$, consequently,
the function $G(q)$ is $\emptyset'$-limitwise monotonic.
\end{proof}
Let us prove theorem in general case.

\begin{proof}[Proof of the theorem \ref{order-equivalence}]
($5\Rightarrow 1$) and ($1\Rightarrow 2$) are trivial.
($3\Rightarrow 4$) and ($4\Rightarrow 5$) are following from
Propositions \ref{lmf-equivalence} and \ref{ltc}. Hence, it remains
to prove ($2\Rightarrow 3$).

($2\Rightarrow 3$) The main idea is the same as in Lemma
\ref{tech-lem}. We use the Cantor normal form of $G(q)$. Suppose
$G(q)=\omega^{\gamma_1(q)}+\omega^{\gamma_2(q)}+\ldots+\omega^{\gamma_m(q)}+k(q)$.
In this prove we have additional complexity because the power of the
last summand may be a limit ordinal. As in Lemma \ref{tech-lem}, we
add $u_\infty$ to $\mathcal{L}$. Suppose $u_\infty>_{\mathcal{L}}u$
for all $u\in L$. We define
$$\gamma_1(q,\,s)=\min(\{0\}\cup\{\gamma\in\omega\mid |\{t\in L\mid t>_\mathcal{L}\varphi^{-1}(q)\,\&\,t<s\,\&$$
$$F^{\gamma+2}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,t)\,\&\,
\neg F^{\gamma+1}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,t) \}|=0\}),$$
$$u_1(q,\,s)=\min\nolimits_\mathcal{L}(\{u_\infty\}\cup\{u\in L\mid
F^{\gamma_1(q,\,s)+1}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,u)\,\&\, \neg
F^{\gamma_1(q,\,s)}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,u) \}),$$
$$\gamma_{i+1}(q,\,s)=\min(\{0\}\cup\{n\in\omega\mid |\{t\in L\mid t\geq_\mathcal{L}u_i(q,\,s)\,\&$$
$$t<s \,\&\, F^{\gamma+2}_\mathcal{L}(u_i(q,\,s),\,t)\,\&\,\neg
F^{\gamma+1}_\mathcal{L}(u_i(q,\,s),\,t)\}|=0\}),$$
$$u_{i+1}(q,\,s)=\min\nolimits_\mathcal{L}(\{u_\infty\}\cup\{u\in L\mid
F^{\gamma_{i+1}(q,\,s)+1}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,u)\,\&\,
\neg F^{\gamma_{i+1}(q,\,s)}_\mathcal{L}(\varphi^{-1}(q),\,u) \}).$$

Suppose $u_f(q,\,s)=\max_\mathcal{L}(\{\varphi^{-1}(q)\}\cup\{u\in
L\mid \exists i<s\,[u=u_i(q,\,s)\,\&\, \gamma_i(q,\,s)=0]\})$. Then we
define $k(q,\,s)=|\{t\in L\mid F^1_\mathcal{L}(u_f(q,\,s),\,t)\}|$.

Let $\hat{g}(q,\,s)=\sum\limits_{i=1}^s
sg(\gamma_i(q,\,s))\cdot\omega^{\gamma_i(q,\,s)}+k(q,\,s)$. We have
$\hat{g}(q,\,s)\leq\hat{g}(q,\,s+1)$ and $\lim\limits_{s\to\infty}
\hat{g}(q,\,s)=G(q).$ The last equation is following from three
cases. The first case and the second case like in Lemma
\ref{tech-lem}.

Case 1. Let
$G(q)=\omega^{\gamma_1(q)}+\omega^{\gamma_2(q)}+\ldots+\omega^{\gamma_m(q)}+k(q)$,
i.e., the last summand is a finite ordinal. Then we
have $\lim\limits_{s\to\infty} \gamma_j(q,\,s)=\gamma_j(q)$ for any
$j\leq m$, $\lim\limits_{s\to\infty} \gamma_j(q,\,s)=0$ for any
$j>m$, and $\lim\limits_{s\to \infty}k(q,\,s)=k(q)$.

Case 2. Let
$G(q)=\omega^{\gamma_1(q)}+\omega^{\gamma_2(q)}+\ldots+\omega^{\gamma_m(q)+1}$,
i.e., the power of the last summand is a successor. Then we have
$\lim\limits_{s\to\infty} \gamma_j(q,\,s)=\gamma_j(q)$ for any
$j<m$, and $\lim\limits_{s\to \infty}\gamma_t(q,\,s)=\gamma_m(q)$
for any $j\geq m$. Hence, $\lim\limits_{s\to
\infty}(\sum\limits_{t=m}^{s}sg(\gamma_t(q,\,s))\cdot\omega^{\gamma_t(q,\,s)}+k(q,\,s))=\omega^{\gamma_m(q)}$.

Case 3. Let
$G(q)=\omega^{\gamma_1(q)}+\omega^{\gamma_2(q)}+\ldots+\omega^{\gamma_m(q)}$,
where $\gamma_m$ is a limit ordinal. Then $\lim\limits_{s\to\infty}
\gamma_j(q,\,s)=\gamma_j(q)$ for any $j<m$, and $\lim\limits_{s\to
\infty}\gamma_m(q,\,s)=\gamma_m(q)$ for any $j=m$. Since the ordinal
$\gamma_j(q,\,s)$ is strictly less then $\gamma_m(q)$ for any $s$
and $j>m$, $\lim\limits_{s\to
\infty}(sg(\gamma_m(q,\,s))\cdot\omega^{\gamma_m(q,\,s)})\leq\lim\limits_{s\to
\infty}(\sum\limits_{t=m}^{s}sg(\gamma_t(q,\,s))\cdot\omega^{\gamma_t(q,\,s)}+k(q,\,s))\leq\omega^{\gamma_m(q)}$.
Hence, $\lim\limits_{s\to
\infty}(\sum\limits_{t=m}^{s}sg(\gamma_t(q,\,s))\cdot\omega^{\gamma_t(q,\,s)}+k(q,\,s))=\omega^{\gamma_m(q)}$.

The remaining part of the proof is similar to Lemma \ref{tech-lem}.
\end{proof}
